item.title: Ticket #263 (Email Notification headers wrong) updated
item.dc:creator: mikelittle
item.description: Not a gmail problem. It was merely gmail that I first spotted the problem and which didn't handle the extra newline in the headers. I get the same in mozilla mail (If I look at the raw email), it's just that mozilla email chooses to silently handle the erroneous header, as I'm sure other MUAs do.

item.title: Ticket #263 (Email Notification headers wrong) updated
item.dc:creator: offline
item.description:
I'd be inclined to suspect that the bug in question lies with Gmail, then -- The old format worked *just* fine with the RFC-compliant line-terminator, but I noticed a change as soon as I switched over to Gmail.

Perhaps someone who is better at describing bugs can contact Gmail with a bug report?

item.title: Ticket #356 (Localization problem, gettext.php) created
item.dc:creator: Albert
item.description:
Upgraded to new php (from 4.3.9) and nightly wordpress after reading that it should work.

Localization did not work afterwards, it returned several error messages Warning: fread(): Length parameter must be greater than 0. in directory/wp-includes/streams.php on line 107

One way to solve the problem is to follow the instructions in ​http://wordpress.org/support/3/14513 problem was solved.

item.title: Ticket #263 (Email Notification headers wrong) updated
item.dc:creator: mikelittle
item.description:
That shouldn't apply to mail headers. The RFC here, ​http://www.faqs.org/rfcs/rfc2822.html , specifies that the line separator for inernet emails is always \r\n (CRLF) This is echoed in the documentation for the mail() function in PHP ​http://de.php.net/manual/en/function.mail.php which says

"Note: You must use \r\n to separate headers, although some Unix mail transfer agents may work with just a single newline (\n)."

item.title: Ticket #263 (Email Notification headers wrong) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
The php manual (​http://de.php.net/mail) has something interesting to say, too:

The comment from "06-Sep-2004 10:03" points out that the line ending is different on different systems. While it is "\n" on Unix/Linux it is "\r" on Mac and "\r\n" on windows. This bug should be fixed in a way to allow wordpress being used on all of these platforms...

item.dc:creator: offline
item.description: Essentially, in the index.php for my site (actually the sidebar.php of the kubrick theme for 1.3 alpha 4-ish) the function is_home() returns false, as do all of the other is_(foo) functions... except is_404(), which returns true. item.title: Ticket #263 (Email Notification headers wrong) updated
item.dc:creator: offline
item.description:
(i posted that above, as well)

I can confirm that the latest version of 1.3 in CVS is fixed by doing a global replace on functions.php

:%s/
r
n/
n/g

(in vim)

What are the possible side effects of this? Why are windows-style line-endings in use at all?

edited on: 10-11-04 03:46

item.title: Ticket #263 (Email Notification headers wrong) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: I've found and fixed this bug on 1.2 and 1.2.1 before -- it seems that in fucntions.php (in those two functions) the line-ending being used is the windows/DOS line-ending of '\r\n' instead of a unix one. Changing those to '\n' fixed the header issue for me.

item.title: Ticket #351 ((more) errors on upgrade) created
item.dc:creator: Jenn99
item.description:
FYI - this happened on my previous test blog (wp 1.2) and a brand NEW install of WP 1.2.1. I attempted an upgrade and got the following error:

Fatal error: Cannot redeclare upgrade_all() (previously declared in /(my server path removed for security issues)/wordpress/wp-admin/upgrade-functions.php:6) in /(my server path removed for security issues)/wordpress/wp-admin/upgrade-functions.php on line 5

If I hit referesh - it goes away.
